Module nl.naturalis.common
Package nl.naturalis.common.check

Class Check<T,​E extends Exception>

  • java.lang.Object
    • nl.naturalis.common.check.Check<T,​E>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of the object being checked
    E - The type of exception thrown if a test fails
    public abstract class Check<T,​E extends Exception>
extends Object
    Facilitates the validation of object state, arguments and array indices. Validating object state and array indices happens through static methods. Validation of arguments happens by means of an actual instance of the Check class. You obtain an instance through one of the static factory methods. For example: 

     this.numChairs = Check.that(numChairs, "numChairs", atLeast(), 2).and(atMost(), 10).and(isEven()).ok();

    Standard checks

    The Checks class contains a number of common checks for arguments. These are already associated with short, informative error messages, so you don't have to invent them yourself. For example: 

     Check.that(numChairs, "numChairs", atLeast(), 2); // "numChairs must be >= 2 (was 0)"

    Checking argument properties

    A Check object lets you check not just arguments but also argument properties. For example: 

     Check.notNull(name, "name").has(String::length, "length", atLeast(), 10);
 Check.notNull(employee, "employee").has(Employee::getAge, "age", lessThan(), 50);
 Check.notNull(employees, "employees").has(Collection::size, "size", atLeast(), 100);
 Check.notNull(intArray, "intArray").and(Array::getLength, "length", isEven());

    The Getters class defines some common getters that you can optionally use for increased conciceness. For example the last two statements could also have been written as: 

     Check.notNull(employees, "employees").has(size(), "size", atLeast(), 100);
 Check.notNull(intArray, "intArray").and(length(), "length", isEven());

    Changing the Exception type

    By default an IllegalArgumentException is thrown if an argument fails to pass a test. This can be customized through the static factory methods. For example: 

     this.query = Check.with(InvalidQueryException::new, query, "query")
  .has(QuerySpec::getFrom, x -> nvl(x) == 0, "from must be null or zero")
  .has(QuerySpec::getSize, "size", atLeast(), MIN_BATCH_SIZE)
  .has(QuerySpec::getSize, "size", atMost(), MAX_BATCH_SIZE)
  .and(QuerySpec::getSortFields, "sortFields", isEmpty())
  .ok();
    Author:
    Ayco Holleman

        public static void that​(boolean condition,
                        String message,
                        Object... msgArgs)
                 throws IllegalArgumentException
        Generic check method. Throws an IllegalArgumentException if the provided condition evaluates to false, else does nothing.
        Parameters:
        condition - The condition to evaluate
        message - The error message
        msgArgs - The message arguments
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the condition to evaluate

      • that

        public static <F extends Exception> void that​(boolean condition,
                                              Supplier<F> excSupplier)
                                       throws F extends Exception
        Generic check method. Throws the exception supplied by the provided supplier if the provided condition evaluates to false, else does nothing.
        Type Parameters:
        F - The type of exception thrown if condition evaluates to false
        Parameters:
        condition - The condition to evaluate
        excSupplier - The exception supplier
        Throws:
        F - The exception thrown if the condition evaluates to false
        F extends Exception

      • index

        public static int index​(int arg,
                        int maxExclusive,
                        String argName)
        Verifies that the argument is a valid array index. Throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException if arg is less than zero or greater than or equal to maxExclusive, else returns arg. This is especially useful to test "from" arguments, which generally should be less than the length or size of the object operated upon.
        Parameters:
        arg - The argument The argument to test
        maxExclusive - The maximum allowed value (exclusive)
        Returns:
        The argument
        Throws:
        ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException

      • index

        public static int index​(int arg,
                        int minInclusive,
                        int MaxInclusive,
                        String argName)
        Verifies that the argument is a valid array index. Throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException if arg is less than min or greater than max, else returns arg. This is especially useful to test "to" or "until" arguments, which generally should be less than or equal to the length or size of the object operated upon.
        Parameters:
        arg - The argument The argument to test
        minInclusive - The minimum allowed value (inclusive)
        MaxInclusive - The maximum allowed value (inclusive)
        Returns:
        The argument
        Throws:
        ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException

      • state

        public static void state​(boolean condition,
                         String message,
                         Object... msgArgs)
                  throws IllegalStateException
        Does nothing if the provided condition evaluates to true, else throws an IllegalStateException.
        Parameters:
        condition - The condition to evaluate
        message - The exception message
        msgArgs - The String.format message arguments
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - If the condition evaluates to false

      • badArgument

        public static Supplier<IllegalArgumentException> badArgument​(String message,
                                                             Object... msgArgs)
        Utility method returning an IllegalArgumentException Supplier using the provided message and message arguments to create an exception message. Can be used in various cases as a static import to avoid bloated code: 

         Check.that(foo.equals(bar), () -> new IllegalArgumentException(String.format("%s must equal %s", foo, bar)));
    // versus:
 Check.that(foo.equals(bar), badArgument("%s must equal %s", foo, bar));
        Parameters:
        message - The exception message
        msgArgs - The String.format message arguments
        Returns:
        An IllegalArgumentException Supplier

      • argName

        public String argName()
        Returns the name of the argument being tested.
        Returns:
        The name of the argument being tested

      • and

        public Check<T,​E> and​(Predicate<T> test)
                     throws E extends Exception
        Submits the argument to the specified test. This method is especially useful when using the (statically imported) tests in thw Checks class, as they have predefined, informative error messages associated with them.
        Parameters:
        test - The test
        Returns:
        This Check object
        Throws:
        E - If the test fails
        E extends Exception

      • and

        public <U> Check<T,​E> and​(Relation<T,​U> relation,
                                U relateTo)
                         throws E extends Exception
        Verifies that there is some relation between the argument and some other value. This method is especially useful when using the (statically imported) tests in thw Checks class, as they have predefined, informative error messages associated with them.
        Type Parameters:
        U - The type of the object of the relationship
        Parameters:
        relation - The relation to verify between the argument and the specified value ( relateTo)
        relateTo - The object of the relationship
        Returns:
        This Check object
        Throws:
        E - If the test fails
        E extends Exception

      • and

      • ok

        public abstract T ok()
        Returns the argument being tested. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks. For example: 
         int age = Check.notNull(employee, "employee").and(Employee::getAge, "age", lessThan(), 50).ok().getAge();
        Returns:
        The argument

      • ok

        public void ok​(Consumer<T> consumer)
        Passes the argument to a Consumer to be properly processed. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks.
        Parameters:
        consumer - The Consumer

      • intValue

        public abstract int intValue()
                      throws E extends Exception
        Returns the argument being tested as an int. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks. Using this method if the argument being tested actually is an int (rather than an Integer), this method saves the cost of a boxing-unboxing round trip incurred by ok(). Otherwise the following applies:

        • If the argument is null, an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
        • If the argument is a Number and the Number can be converted to an integer without loss of precision (it has no fractional part and is not too wide), Number.intValue() will be returned
        • If the argument is a CharSequence and it can be parsed into an integer without loss of precision (it has no fractional part and is not too wide), the value of Integer.parseInt() will be returned
        • If the argument is anything else (including null) an Exception is thrown, the type of which is determined by the <E> type parameter
        Returns:
        The argument cast or converted to an int
        Throws:
        E extends Exception
        See Also:
        NumberMethods.fitsInto(Number, Class)

      • intValue

        public void intValue​(IntConsumer consumer)
              throws E extends Exception
        Passes the argument to a Consumer to be properly processed. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks.
        Parameters:
        consumer - The Consumer
        Throws:
        E extends Exception
